title: Using radioactive drugs to see inside your body - Pedro Brugarolas

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary purpose of injecting FDG (a radioactive form of glucose) into a patient's arm during a PET scan?

options.label: A
options.text: To diagnose infections

options.label: B
options.text: To detect cancer cells

options.label: C
options.text: To track the spread of Alzheimer's disease

options.label: D
options.text: To observe brain function

multiple-choice.question: What type of particle accelerator is used to create fluorine-18, a radioactive isotope used in PET scans?

options.label: A
options.text: Linear accelerator

options.label: B
options.text: Cyclotron

options.label: C
options.text: Magnetron

options.label: D
options.text: Ion accelerator

multiple-choice.question: What happens when a positron emitted from a radioactive isotope collides with an electron in its surroundings?

options.label: A
options.text: It causes a nuclear reaction that produces gamma rays

options.label: B
options.text: It produces two high-energy photons that shoot out in opposite directions

options.label: C
options.text: It causes a chemical reaction that produces a new molecule

options.label: D
options.text: It emits a beta particle that travels in a straight line

multiple-choice.question: How does a PET scanner create a 3D map of the tracer's distribution in the body?

options.label: A
options.text: By detecting the radiation emitted by the tracer and using it to estimate the location of the collision

options.label: B
options.text: By using a magnetic field to align the tracer molecules

options.label: C
options.text: By measuring the temperature of the body

options.label: D
options.text: By observing the movement of the tracer molecules

multiple-choice.question: How does the amount of radiation received during a PET scan compare to natural sources of radiation?

options.label: A
options.text: It is comparable to what you're exposed to in a single year from natural radioactive sources

options.label: B
options.text: It is comparable to what you're exposed to over two or three years from natural radioactive sources

options.label: C
options.text: It is comparable to what you're exposed to in a single day from natural radioactive sources

options.label: D
options.text: It is comparable to what you're exposed to in a lifetime from natural radioactive sources

title: Is it better to walk or run in the rain?

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the amount of rain hitting the top of you when you move out of the way of one falling raindrop?

options.label: A
options.text: It increases.

options.label: B
options.text: It decreases.

options.label: C
options.text: It remains constant.

options.label: D
options.text: It depends on your speed.

multiple-choice.question: Why do you get wetter when you move while running through the rain?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the rain from the top increases.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the rain from the side increases.

options.label: C
options.text: Because you're moving into the way of more raindrops from the side.

options.label: D
options.text: Because you're running into more puddles.

multiple-choice.question: What is the total wetness when running through the rain equal to?

options.label: A
options.text: The wetness per second for rain from the top times the amount of time you spend in the rain.

options.label: B
options.text: The wetness per meter for rain from the side times the number of meters you travel.

options.label: C
options.text: The wetness per second for rain from the top times the amount of time you spend in the rain, plus the wetness per meter for rain from the side times the number of meters you travel.

options.label: D
options.text: The wetness per second for rain from the side times the amount of time you spend in the rain.

multiple-choice.question: To stay driest getting from one point to another, what should you try to minimize?

options.label: A
options.text: The amount of rain falling onto you from the side.

options.label: B
options.text: The amount of rain falling onto you from above.

options.label: C
options.text: The amount of time you spend in the rain.

options.label: D
options.text: The number of meters you travel.

multiple-choice.question: What is the best way to stay driest getting from one point to another?

options.label: A
options.text: Running as fast as possible.

options.label: B
options.text: Standing still.

options.label: C
options.text: Getting out of the rain as fast as possible.

options.label: D
options.text: Jumping into puddles.

title: Can you solve the unstoppable blob riddle? - Dan Finkel

multiple-choice.question: What is the nature of the blob that crashes on Earth?

options.label: A
options.text: It's a living creature that can be killed with a single shot.

options.label: B
options.text: It's a machine that can be destroyed with a single blast.

options.label: C
options.text: It's an unstoppable entity that regrows and continues its rampage despite various attacks.

options.label: D
options.text: It's a natural disaster that can be prevented with early warning systems.

multiple-choice.question: What is the unique property of the acute triangle portion of the blob?

options.label: A
options.text: It wakes up and continues growing after being cut.

options.label: B
options.text: It never "wakes up" and remains inert.

options.label: C
options.text: It has a unique healing property that allows it to regrow faster.

options.label: D
options.text: It has a special shape that makes it more resistant to cuts.

multiple-choice.question: What is the key to cutting the blob into acute triangles and stopping it from destroying the planet?

options.label: A
options.text: Cutting it into small pieces to make it easier to handle.

options.label: B
options.text: Using a special machine that can cut through the blob quickly.

options.label: C
options.text: Cutting off the sharp corners of the blob triangle to create a pentagon, which can then be cut into five acute triangles.

options.label: D
options.text: Using a combination of heat and chemicals to dissolve the blob.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the pizza analogy in solving the problem?

options.label: A
options.text: It shows that cutting the blob into acute triangles is a complex task that requires specialized equipment.

options.label: B
options.text: It illustrates how to cut the blob into obtuse triangles, which will wake up and continue growing.

options.label: C
options.text: It demonstrates how to cut the blob into acute triangles by squaring off the outside of a pizza, resulting in an octagon that can be cut into acute triangles.

options.label: D
options.text: It explains how to use a special machine to cut through the blob quickly.

multiple-choice.question: How many cuts can be made to the blob while it is in its sleeping state?

options.label: A
options.text: 5 cuts

options.label: B
options.text: 7 cuts

options.label: C
options.text: 10 cuts

options.label: D
options.text: 15 cuts

title: How to connect with depressed friends - Bill Bernat

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is one thing that people with depression may do that can make it difficult for others to connect with them?

options.label: A
options.text: They may pretend to be happy all the time.

options.label: B
options.text: They may act in off-putting or confusing ways because they're fighting a war in their head.

options.label: C
options.text: They may be overly critical of themselves.

options.label: D
options.text: They may be too proud to ask for help.

multiple-choice.question: What is one thing should you avoid saying to someone who is depressed?

options.label: A
options.text: "You're so strong for dealing with this."

options.label: B
options.text: "Just get over it."

options.label: C
options.text: "I'm here for you, and I care about you."

options.label: D
options.text: "You're not alone in this."

multiple-choice.question: What is one thing that you can do to help a depressed friend feel more comfortable and in control?

options.label: A
options.text: Give them a lot of advice on how to deal with their depression.

options.label: B
options.text: Clearly state what you can and can't do to help them.

options.label: C
options.text: Tell them that they're not alone and that you're there for them.

options.label: D
options.text: Try to fix their problems for them.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is one way to interact with a depressed friend that can help them feel more connected and valued?

options.label: A
options.text: Ask them to help you with tasks or errands.

options.label: B
options.text: Invite them to contribute to your life in some way, even if it's as small as asking them to go see a movie.

options.label: C
options.text: Try to make them laugh or joke with them.

options.label: D
options.text: Tell them that they're not good enough.

multiple-choice.question: What is the guiding principle that the speaker suggests should guide your interactions with a depressed friend?

options.label: A
options.text: That you should try to fix their problems for them.

options.label: B
options.text: That you should avoid talking to them at all.

options.label: C
options.text: That you should treat them with the same value, intensity, and beauty as you would anyone else.

options.label: D
options.text: That you should only talk to them when they're feeling better.

multiple-choice.question: What is the desired outcome when the second fuse burns out?

options.label: A
options.text: You get a longer time.

options.label: B
options.text: You get a shorter time.

options.label: C
options.text: You get the desired time of 45 seconds.

options.label: D
options.text: You get a random time.

title: How students of color confront imposter syndrome - Dena Simmons

multiple-choice.question: Where did the speaker spend their childhood?

options.label: A
options.text: In a one-bedroom apartment in the Bronx, New York

options.label: B
options.text: In a boarding school in Connecticut

options.label: C
options.text: In a middle school in the Bronx

options.label: D
options.text: In a college in New England

multiple-choice.question: What was the speaker's experience like at boarding school?

options.label: A
options.text: They felt like they belonged and made many friends

options.label: B
options.text: They felt like they didn't belong and were frequently lectured on proper speech

options.label: C
options.text: They were homeschooled and didn't attend school

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's concern about current education reform initiatives?

options.label: A
options.text: That they are not providing enough funding for schools

options.label: B
options.text: That they are not teaching students about themselves and their identities

options.label: C
options.text: That they are not preparing students for college and careers

multiple-choice.question: What did the speaker do to create a safe and supportive classroom when they returned to teach in the Bronx?

options.label: A
options.text: They focused on standardized testing and academic achievement

options.label: B
options.text: They centered their instruction on the lives, histories, and identities of their students

options.label: C
options.text: They implemented a zero-tolerance policy for misbehavior

options.label: D
options.text: They ignored the needs and concerns of their students

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's message to educators and policymakers?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: That they should create emotionally and physically safe classrooms where students can thrive academically

options.label: C

options.label: D

title: Three ways the universe could end - Venus Keus

multiple-choice.question: What is the Big Bang theory, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: The universe's expansion is slowing down.

options.label: B
options.text: The universe's expansion is accelerating.

options.label: C
options.text: The universe began in an incredibly tiny, compact state about 14 billion years ago.

options.label: D
options.text: The universe is getting smaller.

multiple-choice.question: What are the three possible answers for the question of how the universe will end, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: The Big Freeze, the Big Rip, and the Big Crunch

options.label: B
options.text: The Big Bang, the Big Freeze, and the Big Rip

options.label: C
options.text: The Big Crunch, the Big Bounce, and the Big Freeze

options.label: D
options.text: The Big Bang, the Big Crunch, and the Big Bounce

multiple-choice.question: What happens in the Big Freeze scenario, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: The universe contracts and gets denser.

options.label: B
options.text: The universe expands and gets hotter.

options.label: C
options.text: The universe gets bigger and colder, approaching a frozen state.

options.label: D
options.text: The universe gets smaller and denser.

multiple-choice.question: What happens in the Big Rip scenario, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: The universe contracts and gets denser.

options.label: B
options.text: The universe expands and gets hotter.

options.label: C
options.text: The universe breaks apart into tiny pieces, and even atoms and subatomic particles are destroyed.

options.label: D
options.text: The universe gets smaller and denser.

multiple-choice.question: What is the Big Bounce theory, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: The universe expands and contracts over and over again, repeating its entire history.

options.label: B
options.text: The universe gets smaller and denser over time.

options.label: C
options.text: The universe gets bigger and stays in a frozen state.

options.label: D
options.text: The universe gets hotter and stays in a state of constant expansion.

title: The gift and power of emotional courage - Susan David

multiple-choice.question: What does the Zulu word "sawubona" literally mean?

options.label: A
options.text: "Hello, how are you?"

options.label: B
options.text: "I see you, and by seeing you, I bring you into being."

options.label: C
options.text: "I love you."

options.label: D
options.text: "Goodbye."

multiple-choice.question: What is the conventional view of emotions that the speaker argues is rigid?

options.label: A
options.text: Emotions are complex and multifaceted.

options.label: B
options.text: Emotions are good or bad, positive or negative.

options.label: C
options.text: Emotions are data that contain flashing lights to things that we care about.

options.label: D
options.text: Emotions are only present in certain situations.

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of pushing aside normal emotions to embrace false positivity?

options.label: A
options.text: Increased happiness and resilience.

options.label: B
options.text: Decreased capacity to develop skills to deal with the world as it is.

options.label: C
options.text: Increased stress and discomfort.

options.label: D
options.text: None of the above.

multiple-choice.question: What is the cornerstone to resilience, thriving, and true, authentic happiness?

options.label: A
options.text: Emotional suppression.

options.label: B
options.text: False positivity.

options.label: C
options.text: Radical acceptance of all of our emotions.

options.label: D
options.text: Avoiding difficult emotions.

multiple-choice.question: What is emotional agility?

options.label: A
options.text: The ability to suppress or deny emotions.

options.label: B
options.text: The ability to be with emotions with curiosity, compassion, and courage.

options.label: C
options.text: The ability to only feel positive emotions.

options.label: D
options.text: The ability to only feel negative emotions.

title: What is consciousness? - Michael S. A. Graziano

multiple-choice.question: What is the condition known as hemispatial neglect, and how does it affect a person's brain processing information?

options.label: A
options.text: Hemispatial neglect is a condition where a person's brain processes information from only one side of their body, and they are unaware of anything on the other side.

options.label: B
options.text: Hemispatial neglect is a condition where a person's brain processes information from their whole field of vision, but they are unaware of the information on one side.

options.label: C
options.text: Hemispatial neglect is a condition where a person's brain processes information from their whole field of vision, but they are unable to focus on specific objects or events.

options.label: D
options.text: Hemispatial neglect is a condition where a person's brain is unable to process information from their senses, and they are in a vegetative state.

multiple-choice.question: According to the theory that consciousness is the brain's imperfect picture of its own activity, what is the brain's model of itself used for?

options.label: A
options.text: To control focus effectively, the brain has to construct a model of its own attention to direct its focus on specific objects and events.

options.label: B
options.text: To build models of objects and events in the world, the brain needs to construct a model of its own information processing.

options.label: C
options.text: To keep track of the configuration of the body's limbs, the brain needs to construct a model of its own body.

options.label: D
options.text: To process sensory input, the brain needs to construct a model of its own senses.

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of MRI studies that compare patterns of neural activation when someone is and isn't conscious of a sensory stimulus?

options.label: A
options.text: The areas needed for visual processing are activated whether or not the participant is aware of the image.

options.label: B
options.text: A whole additional network lights up only when the participant is conscious of seeing the image.

options.label: C
options.text: The brain's model of its own information processing is perfectly self-descriptive.

options.label: D
options.text: The brain's model of its own attention is not related to consciousness.

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of extensive damage to the network related to consciousness?

options.label: A
options.text: A person may experience a vegetative state with no sign of consciousness.

options.label: B
options.text: A person may experience a coma with no sign of consciousness.

options.label: C
options.text: A person may experience a loss of motor function.

options.label: D
options.text: A person may experience a loss of sensory function.

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the limitations of current technology in understanding how neurons in the networks related to consciousness compute specific pieces of information?

options.label: A
options.text: The brain's model of its own information processing is too complex to understand.

options.label: B
options.text: The brain's model of its own attention is too simple to understand.

options.label: C
options.text: The way neurons in the networks related to consciousness compute specific pieces of information is outside the scope of our current technology.

options.label: D
options.text: The brain's model of its own senses is too vague to understand.

title: Don't ask where I'm from, ask where I'm a local - Taiye Selasi

options.label: A
options.text: The concept of nationality

options.label: B
options.text: The concept of culture

options.label: C
options.text: The concept of locality

options.label: D
options.text: The concept of identity

options.text: Rituals, relationships, and resources

options.label: B
options.text: Rituals, relationships, and restrictions

options.label: C
options.text: Rituals, roles, and responsibilities

options.label: D
options.text: Rituals, routines, and routes

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: The location of the answer

options.label: D
options.text: The language used in the question

options.text: The idea that one can go back to a country and find it exactly where they left it

options.label: B
options.text: The idea that one can go back to a country and experience it as a tourist

options.label: C
options.text: The idea that one can go back to a country and find it exactly as it was in the past

options.label: D
options.text: The idea that one can go back to a country and find it exactly where they left it, but with changes

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of locality in creative writing?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: It makes the characters less relatable

options.label: C
options.text: It bespeaks humanity and makes the characters more relatable

options.label: D
options.text: It adds background noise to the story

title: The disarming case to act right now on climate change - Greta Thunberg

multiple-choice.question: What was the speaker's experience with climate change when they were 8 years old?

options.label: A
options.text: They were convinced that humans were capable of changing the Earth's climate.

options.label: B
options.text: They were told to turn off the lights to save energy and to recycle paper to save resources.

options.label: C
options.text: They were told that climate change was an existential threat and the most important issue of all.

options.label: D
options.text: They were convinced that climate change was not a real issue.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's diagnosis, and how has it affected their life?

options.label: A
options.text: The speaker has ADHD and has struggled with social interactions.

options.label: B
options.text: The speaker has Asperger syndrome, OCD, and selective mutism, and has struggled with depression and weight loss.

options.label: C
options.text: The speaker has autism and has struggled with anxiety and fear of change.

options.label: D
options.text: The speaker has depression and has struggled with anxiety and fear of social interactions.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's opinion on why people don't take action on climate change?

options.label: A
options.text: People don't take action because they are too busy with their daily lives.

options.label: B
options.text: People don't take action because they are unaware of the consequences of their actions.

options.label: C
options.text: People don't take action because they are evil and want to harm the planet.

options.label: D
options.text: People don't take action because they are waiting for someone else to do it.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's goal with the school strike for climate?

options.label: A
options.text: The speaker wants to raise awareness about climate change and inspire others to take action.

options.label: B
options.text: The speaker wants to become a climate scientist and solve the climate crisis.

options.label: C
options.text: The speaker wants to attend school and learn about climate change.

options.label: D
options.text: The speaker wants to ignore the climate crisis and focus on other issues.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's message to the audience?

options.label: A
options.text: The speaker wants to inspire hope and positivity about climate change.

options.label: B
options.text: The speaker wants to encourage people to take action and make changes to reduce emissions.

options.label: C
options.text: The speaker wants to educate people about the facts and solutions to climate change.

options.label: D
options.text: The speaker wants to blame others for not taking action on climate change.

title: How do ocean currents work? - Jennifer Verduin

multiple-choice.question: What event in 1992 led to the study of ocean currents?

options.label: A
options.text: A volcanic eruption

options.label: B
options.text: A cargo ship carrying bath toys got caught in a storm

options.label: C
options.text: A hurricane hit a coastal city

options.label: D
options.text: A tsunami struck a remote island

multiple-choice.question: What are the two main categories of ocean currents?

options.label: A
options.text: Surface currents and ocean tides

options.label: B
options.text: Surface currents and deep ocean currents

options.label: C
options.text: Wind-driven currents and thermohaline circulation

options.label: D
options.text: Tidal currents and ocean waves

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary force behind surface currents in the open ocean?

options.label: A
options.text: Tides

options.label: B
options.text: Wind

options.label: C
options.text: Changes in water density

options.label: D
options.text: The rotation of the Earth

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the phenomenon where the Earth's rotation affects the wind patterns that give rise to surface currents?

options.label: A
options.text: The Coriolis Effect

options.label: B
options.text: The Global Conveyor Belt

options.label: C
options.text: The Thermohaline Circulation

options.label: D
options.text: The Ocean Gyre

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the global current that combines wind-driven surface currents and thermohaline circulation?

options.label: A
options.text: The Global Conveyor Belt

options.label: B
options.text: The Ocean Circulation System

options.label: C
options.text: The Thermohaline Current

options.label: D
options.text: The Surface Water Current
